stem: The triage nurse is assessing two clients in the third trimester presenting with vaginal bleeding. Based on the documentation in the Antepartum Hemorrhage Flowsheet, match each assessment finding to the appropriate condition.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 34-week G2P1. Presents with sudden, bright red vaginal bleeding. She states she has no pain. 
Patient B: 36-week G1P0 with history of chronic Hypertension. Presents with dark red vaginal bleeding and 'tearing' abdominal pain. Her uterus feels very firm to the touch.

tabs.title: Antepartum Hemorrhage Flowsheet
tabs.content:
AssessmentPatient APatient B
Pain Level0/109/10 (Sharp)
Bleeding ColorBright RedDark Red/Clotted
Uterine ToneSoft; RelaxedRigid; 'Board-like'
Fetal Heart Rate145 (Stable)110 (Late decels noted)

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Patient A: BP 118/72, HR 82. 
Patient B: BP 152/98, HR 118 (Tachycardia).

rows.text: Risk: Maternal Hypertension or Cocaine use

rationale.correct: Placenta Previa (c1) is characterized by **Painless** bright red bleeding (r1) and a soft uterus (r3) because the placenta is merely misplaced over the cervix. Placental Abruption (c2) is a premature separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, leading to severe pain (r2), a rigid 'board-like' abdomen (r4), and is highly associated with hypertension/vasoconstriction (r5).
clinicalPearls: In Placenta Previa, NO VAGINAL EXAMS (Digital exams) are allowed until an ultrasound is performed.
Abruption is a hidden medical emergency; the patient can bleed internally (concealed) without seeing much blood externally.
The 'Board-like' abdomen is an NCLEX classic for Abruption.

questionTrap.trap: Believing that both conditions always have bright red blood.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Previa = Pretty (Bright) red blood'. 'Abruption = Abrupt pain/Dark blood'.

mnemonic.title: The P's and A's
mnemonic.expansion: Previa = Painless, Pretty red. Abruption = Agony, Abrupt, Always a firm uterus.
